novel_text:
The rain hammered against the workshop windows with the persistence of an old debt collector, each droplet carrying the weight of another grey Belfast morning. Siobhan O'Malley wiped sawdust from her calloused hands and stepped back to admire the oak cabinet she'd been crafting for the past three weeks. The grain flowed like music across its surface, each whorl and line telling stories older than the troubles that had shaped her city.

At thirty-two, Siobhan had inherited more than just her father's workshop on Cromwell Street. She'd inherited his stubborn streak, his eye for detail, and his complete inability to suffer fools gladly. What she hadn't inherited was his easy way with people or his knack for making friends in high places. Those skills might have served her better in a trade still dominated by men who looked at her calloused hands and grease-stained apron with barely concealed skepticism.

The bell above her workshop door chimed, and Declan Murphy shouldered his way inside, shaking raindrops from his wool coat. Her step-brother moved through the world with the confidence of someone who'd never doubted his place in it, his dark hair perfectly styled despite the weather, his smile as practiced as a politician's handshake.

"Still playing with your toys, I see," he said, running a manicured finger along the cabinet's edge. "Though I'll admit, this one's not half bad."

Siobhan bristled. "Playing? This piece is going to the Merchant Hotel. They're paying three thousand pounds for my toys."

"Three thousand?" Declan's eyebrows rose. "Christ, maybe I should have learned to swing a hammer instead of studying law."

"You'd have needed to develop actual skills first." The words slipped out before she could stop them, sharp as the chisels hanging on her wall. Declan's smile faltered for just a moment before reassembling itself.

"Always the charmer, our Siobhan. Listen, I didn't come here to trade insults. Mam wants us both for Sunday dinner. Apparently, she's got some announcement to make."

Their mother, Patricia, had married Siobhan's father when Siobhan was barely fifteen. The woman had swept into their lives like a hurricane, reorganizing everything from the spice rack to their social calendar. When Siobhan's father died two years later, Patricia had stayed, bringing her own son Declan into the fold with his university education and his grand plans for the future.

"I'll be there," Siobhan said, though the prospect filled her with the same enthusiasm she reserved for root canals and tax audits.

Declan lingered by the door, his confidence seeming to waver. "There's something else. I've been meaning to tell you... I've met someone."

"Congratulations. Does she know about your personality yet?"

"Her name's Aoife Brennan. She's a teacher at St. Mary's Primary. And before you say anything cutting, I actually think this might be serious."

Something in his tone made Siobhan look up from her work. Declan's usual swagger had been replaced by something almost vulnerable, a crack in the armor he usually wore so effortlessly.

"Well then," she said, softer now. "I suppose I should meet this miracle worker who's managed to improve your disposition."

After Declan left, Siobhan returned to her work, but concentration proved elusive. The workshop felt smaller somehow, the familiar sounds of sanding and sawing unable to drown out the restlessness that had been growing in her chest for months. She'd always found solace in creating things with her hands, in transforming rough lumber into objects of beauty and function. But lately, even that satisfaction felt hollow.

The accident happened just after five o'clock, as the autumn light was fading into the purple dusk that settled over Belfast like a worn blanket. Siobhan was adjusting the blade on her table saw when the phone rang. Startled, she jerked backward, her elbow catching the edge of a paint can perched precariously on her workbench. The can tumbled, spilling wood stain across the concrete floor in a spreading pool of amber.

She lunged forward to catch the can, her foot slipping on the wet surface. Time seemed to slow as she felt herself falling, her head aimed directly for the corner of her workbench. In that suspended moment between balance and catastrophe, something strange happened. The world around her seemed to shift, colors bleeding together like watercolors in rain. She felt herself becoming lighter, less substantial, as if she were dissolving into the very air around her.

When she hit the ground, she felt no pain. In fact, she felt nothing at all. Confused, she pushed herself to her feet and looked around the workshop. Everything appeared normal except for one impossible detail: she couldn't see herself. Where her body should have been, there was nothing but empty space.

Panic rose in her throat like bile. She ran to the small mirror she kept by the washbasin, but her reflection was nowhere to be found. Only the workshop behind her stared back, complete and undisturbed. She waved her hands in front of the glass, but nothing moved except the shadows cast by the overhead lights.

"What the hell," she whispered, though she couldn't see her lips moving. The sound seemed to come from everywhere and nowhere at once.

She tried to convince herself it was a head injury, a hallucination brought on by the fall. But when she looked down at her hands, there was nothing there. She could feel them, could move her fingers and clench her fists, but they existed in a world beyond sight.

Over the next hour, she experimented with her condition like a scientist studying a new species. She could touch objects, could feel their texture and weight, but she cast no shadow and made no reflection. When she walked past the windows facing the street, pedestrians looked through her as if she were made of glass and air.

The invisibility lasted exactly three hours and seventeen minutes. She knew because she'd been watching the clock on her workbench when her body began to materialize again, starting with her fingertips and spreading up her arms like morning light chasing away shadows. The sensation was neither painful nor pleasant, simply strange, as if she were remembering how to exist in the physical world.

When she was fully visible again, she sat heavily on her work stool and tried to process what had happened. In a city where the impossible was usually reserved for ghost stories and political promises, she had somehow stepped outside the boundaries of the visible world and returned to tell the tale.The workshop fell silent except for the steady drumming of rain against glass and the distant hum of Belfast traffic. Siobhan stared at her hands, turning them over in the lamplight, searching for some sign that they had been translucent mere minutes before. Her palms looked exactly as they always had—scarred from years of woodworking, a thin white line across her left thumb from a chisel that had slipped when she was seventeen, calluses thick as leather from gripping tools. Nothing had changed, yet everything felt different.

She stood on unsteady legs and walked to the window, pressing her palm against the cool glass. Her reflection stared back, solid and undeniable. A woman with auburn hair escaping from its ponytail, green eyes wide with confusion, wearing the same paint-splattered work clothes she'd put on that morning. But the memory of looking into the mirror and seeing nothing lingered like smoke in her mind, too vivid to dismiss as imagination.

The logical part of her brain, the part that measured twice and cut once, that understood angles and grain patterns and the precise amount of pressure needed to drive a screw without splitting wood, scrambled for explanations. Concussion from the fall, perhaps. She'd heard of head injuries causing hallucinations, though she couldn't remember hitting her head. Or maybe she'd inhaled too many paint fumes—the workshop ventilation had never been what it should be, despite her best efforts to improve it. But even as she grasped for rational causes, something deeper knew with absolute certainty that what had happened was real.

The phone rang again, the sound sharp enough to make her jump. She let it ring twice before answering, her voice catching slightly as she spoke. "O'Malley Woodworking."

"Siobhan, love, where have you been? I've been trying to reach you for ages." Her mother's voice carried the particular blend of affection and exasperation that Patricia had perfected over the years. "I wanted to make sure you remembered about Sunday dinner. We're having it at three instead of the usual time because Father McKenna is coming by afterward to discuss the church renovation project."

"I'll be there," Siobhan managed, though the normalcy of the conversation felt surreal after what she'd experienced. Her mother continued talking about menu plans and whether Declan would bring his new girlfriend, but the words seemed to come from very far away. How could the world continue spinning on its axis when she had just discovered that the fundamental rules of existence were apparently more flexible than she'd ever imagined?

After hanging up, she began the ritual of closing the workshop, a routine so ingrained she could do it in her sleep. Tools returned to their designated places on the pegboard, wood scraps sorted into bins for future projects, surfaces wiped clean of dust and debris. The familiar tasks helped ground her, each completed action a small anchor to reality. But as she swept up the spilled wood stain, now dried to a sticky amber patch on the concrete floor, she couldn't shake the feeling that she was playacting at normalcy.

The walk home through the narrow streets of Belfast should have been comforting. She'd taken this route thousands of times, past the corner shop where Mrs. Kelly always had a smile and a comment about the weather, past the pub where her father used to stop for a pint after work, past the small terraced houses with their brightly painted doors and postage-stamp gardens. Tonight, though, the familiar sights felt like a movie set, as if she were observing them from behind glass rather than moving through them as a participant.

Her flat occupied the upper floor of a Victorian house that had been converted into apartments sometime in the 1980s. The renovation had been done on the cheap, with thin walls that meant she knew more about her neighbors' lives than she cared to, and plumbing that groaned and complained at the slightest provocation. But it was hers, bought with money saved from years of careful budgeting and the small inheritance her father had left her. The independence it represented mattered more than its shortcomings.

She climbed the narrow staircase, her footsteps echoing in the hallway, and let herself into the flat. The living room was small but comfortable, furnished with pieces she'd made herself—a coffee table crafted from reclaimed barn wood, bookshelves that fit perfectly into the alcoves on either side of the fireplace, a rocking chair that had been her first major project after taking over the workshop. Creating furniture for her own space had always given her a particular satisfaction, each piece chosen and shaped to suit her needs exactly.

Tonight, though, even these familiar objects felt somehow foreign. She moved through the flat like a guest, touching surfaces tentatively, as if testing whether her fingers would pass through them like a ghost's. In the bathroom mirror, her reflection looked back with wide, uncertain eyes. She touched her face, watching her mirror-self mirror the motion, reassuring herself that she was fully present in the world.

The kettle's whistle broke the silence, and she made herself a cup of tea with hands that only trembled slightly. She settled into her chair by the window, cradling the warm mug, and tried to make sense of what had happened. In the stories she'd grown up with, the old tales her grandmother had whispered on winter nights, strange things happened to ordinary people. Fishermen's daughters became selkies, farmers' sons found doorways to other worlds, and sometimes, just sometimes, the barriers between the possible and impossible grew thin as morning mist.

But those were stories, tales told to pass dark evenings and make children's eyes grow wide with wonder. She lived in the twenty-first century, in a world of mobile phones and satellite television, where mysteries were solved by forensic science and magic was something that happened on stage for paying audiences. Yet she couldn't deny what she had experienced, couldn't rationalize away the memory of looking down at her hands and seeing nothing but empty air.Sleep came in fragments that night, interrupted by dreams where she dissolved into mist and reformed like morning fog. Each time she jolted awake, her first instinct was to look at her hands in the dim light filtering through the curtains, confirming their solid presence before her racing heart could settle. The digital clock beside her bed marked the hours with relentless precision: 2:17 AM, 3:42 AM, 4:58 AM. By the time pale dawn crept across the Belfast sky, she had given up any pretense of rest and padded to the kitchen to make coffee, her bare feet silent on the cold linoleum.

The morning routine of showering and dressing felt like an act of faith. Each mundane action—brushing her teeth, pulling on jeans and a wool sweater, tying her work boots—served as proof that she remained anchored in the physical world. In the harsh bathroom light, she examined her reflection with the thoroughness of a detective studying evidence. Same freckles scattered across her nose, same scar through her left eyebrow from childhood chickenpox, same stubborn cowlick that made her hair stick up at odd angles no matter how much product she used. Everything exactly as it should be, yet the memory of her absent reflection from the previous evening lingered like a persistent ache.

The workshop felt different when she unlocked the door that morning, though she couldn't pinpoint exactly what had changed. The same tools hung in their designated places, the same projects waited in various stages of completion, the same scent of sawdust and wood stain permeated the air. But something ineffable had shifted, as if the very atoms of the space had been rearranged in some subtle way that only she could sense. She moved through her usual opening ritual—checking the moisture levels in her lumber, reviewing the day's planned tasks, setting up her work area—but her movements felt mechanical, disconnected from the joy she usually found in these preparations.

Her first client of the day arrived at nine o'clock sharp. Mrs. Henderson was a retired teacher who had commissioned a custom bookshelf for her sitting room, something to house her collection of first edition mysteries and romance novels. She was a precise woman who knew exactly what she wanted and wasn't shy about expressing her opinions, qualities that Siobhan normally appreciated in a customer. Today, though, she found it difficult to focus on the conversation, her attention drifting even as Mrs. Henderson discussed wood stain options and shelf spacing with passionate intensity.

"The spacing between the shelves needs to accommodate my larger volumes," Mrs. Henderson was saying, running her fingers along the partially completed frame. "I have several books that are quite tall, and I'd hate for them to not fit properly after all this work." She paused, studying Siobhan's face with the sharp attention of someone who had spent decades reading the moods of schoolchildren. "Are you feeling alright, dear? You seem a bit distracted this morning."

Siobhan forced herself to focus, pushing down the swirling questions about her experience the night before. "Just tired, Mrs. Henderson. I stayed up too late working on another project. Let me show you how I've planned the adjustable shelving system." She guided the older woman's attention to the intricate arrangement of dados and cleats that would allow the shelves to be repositioned as needed, losing herself momentarily in the technical details. This was familiar ground, the intersection of engineering and artistry that had always made woodworking feel more like puzzle-solving than manual labor.

After Mrs. Henderson left, satisfied with the progress and full of praise for Siobhan's craftsmanship, the workshop settled back into its usual quiet rhythm. Siobhan threw herself into her work with desperate intensity, as if the physical act of shaping wood could somehow restore the order that had been disrupted in her world. The piece she was working on was a dining table commissioned by a young couple for their first home, crafted from a single slab of walnut that had taken her months to properly season. The grain was spectacular, flowing across the surface like a frozen river, and under normal circumstances she would have lost herself completely in the meditative process of sanding and finishing.

But concentration proved elusive. Her mind kept returning to those impossible three hours, turning the experience over like a puzzle piece that refused to fit into any recognizable pattern. She had always prided herself on being practical, on understanding the world through direct experience and careful observation. Her father had taught her to trust her hands and her eyes, to measure twice and cut once, to base decisions on evidence rather than wishful thinking. Yet here she was, grappling with something that defied every principle she had built her life around.

The lunch hour brought a brief reprieve when Maeve Donnelly stopped by with sandwiches from the café down the street. Maeve owned the flower shop next door and had become something approaching a friend over the three years since Siobhan had taken over the workshop. She was a woman of fierce opinions and boundless curiosity, with graying red hair that she wore in an elaborate braid and a laugh that could be heard three blocks away. More importantly, she was one of the few people who treated Siobhan's work with the respect it deserved, never questioning whether a woman could handle power tools or understand the intricacies of joinery.

"You look like something the cat dragged in," Maeve announced cheerfully, setting down a paper bag that smelled of fresh bread and corned beef. "Rough night, was it? Don't tell me you were out carousing with that brother of yours." She settled herself on a stack of lumber that Siobhan had been meaning to move for weeks, making herself comfortable with the ease of someone who considered the workshop a second home.

Siobhan accepted the sandwich gratefully, realizing she had forgotten to eat breakfast in her distracted state. "Declan's not my brother," she corrected automatically, though she knew Maeve was well aware of the technicality. "And no, I wasn't carousing. Just didn't sleep well." The lie came easily, but it sat uncomfortably in her stomach alongside the first bite of sandwich. She had never been good at deception, lacking the natural charm that made dishonesty seem effortless for some people.

Maeve studied her with the penetrating gaze that made her such a successful shopkeeper, able to read customers' moods and desires with uncanny accuracy. "Something's bothering you beyond just a bad night's sleep. You've got that look you get when you're trying to solve a particularly complicated joint." She bit into her own sandwich, chewing thoughtfully. "Want to talk about it, or should I mind my own business for once in my life?"

The temptation to confess everything was almost overwhelming. Maeve was practical but not closed-minded, the sort of person who might listen to an impossible story without immediately suggesting psychiatric evaluation or religious intervention. But the words seemed to stick in Siobhan's throat like sawdust. How could she begin to explain what had happened when she didn't understand it herself? How could she describe becoming invisible without sounding like she had suffered some kind of breakdown?

"Just work stuff," she said finally, hating herself for the half-truth. "Trying to figure out the best approach for a complicated piece." It wasn't entirely false—she was trying to figure out the best approach for dealing with something that seemed to defy all reasonable approaches. The problem was that this particular puzzle involved her own existence rather than wood grain and structural engineering.**Chapter 2**

Sunday arrived with the kind of crisp October morning that made Belfast look almost picturesque, the weak sunlight catching the wet cobblestones and turning them into mirrors that reflected the grey stone buildings. Siobhan dressed carefully for the family dinner, choosing a navy blue sweater that her stepmother had given her for Christmas two years ago and a pair of trousers that weren't stained with wood finish. The effort felt performative, like putting on a costume for a role she wasn't entirely sure she knew how to play. The events of Friday evening had left her feeling disconnected from ordinary social interactions, as if she were viewing the world through a pane of glass that no one else could see.

Patricia O'Malley lived in a semi-detached house in the Malone area, the kind of neighborhood where the gardens were properly maintained and the cars in the driveways suggested comfortable middle-class prosperity. She had bought the house after Siobhan's father died, using his life insurance money and her own savings from her job as a hospital administrator. It was a sensible choice, close to her work and large enough to accommodate visits from Declan when he was home from university, but it had never felt like home to Siobhan. The rooms were decorated in shades of cream and sage green, everything coordinated and tasteful, without the comfortable clutter that had characterized the house where she had grown up with her father.

The front door opened before Siobhan could knock, revealing Patricia in full hostess mode, wearing a floral apron over a cashmere cardigan and emanating the particular energy that came from having spent the morning cooking for company. At fifty-three, Patricia maintained the kind of careful appearance that suggested regular salon visits and a disciplined approach to both diet and exercise. Her dark hair showed no trace of grey, and her makeup was applied with the precision of someone who had learned early that presentation mattered in both professional and social contexts.

"Siobhan, love, you're right on time," Patricia said, enveloping her stepdaughter in a brief hug that smelled of expensive perfume and roasting lamb. "Come in out of the cold. Declan's already here, and he's brought Aoife to meet us. She seems like a lovely girl, very polite and well-spoken. I think you'll like her." The words tumbled out in the rapid-fire delivery that indicated Patricia was nervous about something, though whether it was the prospect of introducing a new potential family member or whatever announcement she had planned remained unclear.

The sitting room was warm and filled with the kind of golden afternoon light that made everything look softer around the edges. Declan stood near the fireplace, looking more relaxed than Siobhan had seen him in months, his arm around a petite woman with dark hair and intelligent brown eyes. Aoife Brennan appeared to be in her late twenties, with the kind of natural beauty that didn't require enhancement and the confident posture of someone comfortable in her own skin. She wore a simple green dress that complemented her coloring and a smile that seemed genuine rather than perfunctory.

"Siobhan, I'd like you to meet Aoife," Declan said, and there was something in his voice that Siobhan had never heard before, a warmth that suggested this introduction mattered to him in ways that went beyond casual politeness. "Aoife, this is my sister Siobhan, the master craftsperson I've been telling you about." The use of 'sister' rather than 'step-sister' was deliberate, Siobhan realized, an attempt to present a united family front that glossed over the complicated dynamics that actually existed between them.

Aoife stepped forward with her hand extended, her grip firm and her gaze direct. "It's wonderful to finally meet you. Declan's told me so much about your work. I have to admit, I'm a bit envious of anyone who can create beautiful things with their hands. The closest I come to craftsmanship is making construction paper decorations for my classroom." Her accent carried the musical cadences of County Cork, and when she smiled, her whole face lit up in a way that made it impossible not to smile back.

Despite her preoccupation with her recent strange experience, Siobhan found herself genuinely liking this woman. There was nothing artificial about Aoife's manner, none of the calculated charm that characterized the previous girlfriends Declan had brought around for family inspection. She seemed genuinely interested in other people, asking thoughtful questions and listening to the answers with focused attention. When Patricia bustled around serving drinks and arranging cushions, Aoife offered to help without being asked, moving naturally into the rhythm of domestic preparation as if she had been part of the family for years rather than hours.

The meal itself passed pleasantly enough, with conversation flowing around topics both trivial and substantial. Aoife shared stories from her classroom that were both funny and touching, painting vivid pictures of eight-year-old philosophers and playground diplomats. Patricia dominated much of the discussion with updates on her work at the hospital, the ongoing renovation of the church where she served on the board of trustees, and the latest developments in the lives of various friends and neighbors. Declan contributed observations about his legal practice, though Siobhan noticed he was careful to avoid the more sordid details of some of his cases, perhaps out of deference to mixed company or maybe because he was genuinely trying to be more considerate of others' sensibilities.

For her part, Siobhan found it difficult to concentrate fully on the conversation. Part of her attention remained fixed on her hands as they cut meat and lifted her wine glass, still half-expecting them to flicker out of visibility at any moment. The sensation was like waiting for a shoe to drop or for thunder to follow lightning, a constant low-level anxiety that made it hard to fully engage with the social dynamics around the table. She caught herself staring at her reflection in the polished surface of Patricia's good silverware, reassuring herself that her image remained visible and solid.

It wasn't until Patricia served the apple tart and poured the coffee that she finally broached the subject that had clearly been weighing on her mind throughout the meal. Her manner became slightly more formal, the way it did when she was chairing a committee meeting or delivering difficult news to patients' families. She smoothed her napkin carefully and cleared her throat, a small gesture that immediately commanded everyone's attention.

"I asked you all here today because I have something important to share," she began, her voice carrying the measured cadence of someone who had rehearsed this speech several times. "As you know, I'll be turning fifty-five next month, and I've been doing a lot of thinking about the future, about what I want the next phase of my life to look like." She paused, glancing around the table at each of them in turn, her expression mixing excitement with apprehension.

Siobhan felt a cold knot of dread forming in her stomach, though she couldn't have articulated exactly what she was afraid of hearing. Change had always made her uncomfortable, particularly changes that were outside her control. She preferred the predictable rhythms of her work, the satisfaction of projects that progressed according to plan and deadlines that could be met through careful preparation and steady effort. Family announcements, in her experience, tended to involve disruption and complications that couldn't be solved with proper planning and attention to detail.

"I've been offered a position with Médecins Sans Frontières," Patricia continued, her words gaining momentum as she warmed to her subject. "It's a two-year commitment, initially in South Sudan, working to establish better medical infrastructure in underserved communities. It's something I've thought about for years, but the timing was never right when you were younger and needed more stability at home." She looked directly at Declan and then at Siobhan, her expression mixing maternal concern with personal excitement. "But now you're both adults with your own lives and careers, and I feel like this might be my last opportunity to do something truly meaningful on an international scale."

The silence that followed was heavy with unspoken reactions. Declan set down his coffee cup with careful precision, his lawyer's training helping him maintain composure even when processing unexpected information. Aoife looked between the siblings, clearly sensing the emotional undercurrents but uncertain how to navigate them as the newest member of the group. Siobhan found herself staring at her stepmother as if seeing her for the first time, trying to reconcile this woman who dreamed of humanitarian adventures with the careful homemaker who worried about coordinated table settings and properly ironed napkins.

"South Sudan," Declan said finally, his voice neutral in the way that meant he was working hard to keep his emotions in check. "That's quite a change from Belfast. When would you be leaving?" The question was practical, but Siobhan could hear the underlying concern, the son's worry about his mother venturing into dangerous territory far from the safety of familiar surroundings.

Patricia's smile was both excited and nervous, the expression of someone who had made a decision that felt both thrilling and terrifying. "If everything goes according to plan, I'd leave in January. There's a training program in Brussels first, then orientation in Kenya before deployment to the field site. I know it seems sudden, but I've actually been in discussions with them for several months now. I wanted to wait until everything was confirmed before saying anything, in case it fell through and got everyone worried for nothing."

The conversation that followed was a careful dance of support and concern, with everyone trying to process the implications while maintaining an appropriately positive facade. Aoife was the first to offer genuine congratulations, perhaps because she had no complicated history with Patricia to navigate, no mixed feelings about stepfamily relationships to cloud her response. Declan asked practical questions about safety protocols and communication arrangements, his legal mind focusing on concrete details as a way of managing his emotional reaction. Siobhan found herself struggling to formulate any response at all, caught between admiration for Patricia's courage and a selfish panic about how this change might affect the delicate balance of relationships she had finally learned to navigate.

As the afternoon wore on and the conversation gradually shifted to other topics, Siobhan became increasingly aware of feeling like an observer rather than a participant. She watched Declan's hand resting on Aoife's shoulder, noted the way Patricia's eyes lit up when she talked about her future adventures, observed the easy camaraderie that seemed to flow naturally between the other three while she remained somehow outside the circle. It was a familiar feeling, this sense of being slightly removed from normal human connections, but it seemed more pronounced today, as if her experience with invisibility had somehow made her partially transparent even when she was fully visible.

When the time came to leave, Siobhan was among the first to gather her coat and make excuses about early morning work commitments. The hugs and kisses goodbye felt perfunctory, social obligations fulfilled rather than genuine expressions of affection. Patricia walked her to the door, her manner carrying the particular mix of concern and exasperation that characterized many of their interactions.

"You're being very quiet about all this," Patricia said, her voice pitched low enough that the others couldn't overhear. "I hope you know that this decision isn't about running away from family responsibilities or anything like that. It's just something I need to do for myself, something I've dreamed about for a long time." She paused, studying Siobhan's face with the clinical attention that made her such an effective medical administrator. "You understand that, don't you? The need to do something meaningful with your skills, even if it involves risk?"

Siobhan nodded, though she wasn't entirely sure she did understand. Her own relationship with risk was complicated, shaped by years of learning to navigate a male-dominated profession where mistakes were often magnified and success had to be earned again and again. The idea of voluntarily placing herself in a dangerous situation for the sake of personal fulfillment seemed both admirable and incomprehensible, like watching someone choose to climb a mountain she would have spent considerable effort trying to avoid.

"I think it's wonderful," she said finally, the words feeling both true and inadequate. "You should definitely go." It was the response that was expected, the socially appropriate thing to say, but it carried genuine emotion beneath the conventional phrasing. Patricia had always been more mother to her than she had been willing to acknowledge, and the thought of her venturing into war zones and medical emergencies triggered protective instincts that Siobhan hadn't realized she possessed.

The walk home through the gathering dusk gave her time to process the day's revelations, though she found herself no closer to understanding her own reactions by the time she reached her flat. Change was coming whether she was ready for it or not, reshaping the family dynamics she had spent years learning to navigate. Patricia would be gone, pursuing adventures that would take her to the other side of the world. Declan would probably marry Aoife, starting a new chapter that would further shift the balance of relationships and obligations. And she would be left to figure out her own path forward, armed with woodworking skills, a mysterious new ability that she didn't understand, and a growing sense that her carefully ordered life was about to become significantly more complicated.

The evening stretched ahead of her, empty and full of possibilities she wasn't sure she was ready to explore. She made herself another cup of tea and settled into her reading chair, but the book she had been enjoying the previous week now seemed to require more concentration than she could manage. Instead, she found herself staring out the window at the lights beginning to twinkle across Belfast, wondering what other changes might be coming and whether she would have any control over them when they arrived.**Chapter 3**

The second occurrence happened on a Wednesday morning exactly six days after Patricia's dinner announcement, while Siobhan was installing hardware on a set of kitchen cabinets for a renovation project in the Titanic Quarter. The irony of the location wasn't lost on her—working in Belfast's symbol of maritime ambition and spectacular failure while grappling with her own inexplicable transformation. She had been trying to convince herself that the first incident was an isolated event, perhaps brought on by stress or fatigue or some combination of factors that wouldn't repeat themselves under normal circumstances. The human mind, she had reasoned, was remarkably adept at creating false memories when under pressure, and the death of her father, the complexities of family relationships, and the demands of running a business could certainly qualify as pressure enough to cause temporary psychological disruption.

But as she reached for a cabinet door handle, testing the smooth operation of the European hinges she had installed with painstaking precision, her reflection in the stainless steel appliances began to flicker like a television with poor reception. The familiar sensation of weightlessness crept up her arms, starting at her fingertips and spreading through her body with the inexorable progress of incoming tide. This time she was prepared enough to set down her tools before the transformation completed itself, watching with a mixture of fascination and terror as her hands became translucent, then transparent, then completely absent from the visible spectrum.

The kitchen around her continued to exist in full detail—the granite countertops she had spent hours measuring to ensure perfect cabinet alignment, the custom crown molding that had required three attempts to get the angles exactly right, the morning sunlight streaming through windows that overlooked Belfast Lough in the distance. But she had once again stepped outside the boundaries of normal existence, become a observer rather than a participant in the physical world. The sensation was simultaneously liberating and terrifying, like discovering she could fly but only while falling off a cliff.

This time, however, she was not alone in the space when the transformation occurred. The homeowner, a software engineer named David Cromwell who worked for one of the tech companies that had transformed this area of Belfast from industrial wasteland into gleaming office parks and luxury apartments, was due to return from a business trip that afternoon. But his cleaning lady, Mrs. Flanagan, had arrived early for her weekly visit and was working her way through the lower floor with the methodical efficiency of someone who had been cleaning other people's homes for three decades. Siobhan could hear the vacuum cleaner running in the living room, punctuated by the occasional sound of furniture being moved to allow access to difficult corners.

The ethical implications of her situation struck her immediately. She was effectively eavesdropping on someone who believed herself to be alone, witnessing private moments that weren't meant for observation by others. The cleaning lady had every right to go about her work without worrying about invisible spectators, and Siobhan felt the uncomfortable weight of being an unwitting voyeur. The first time Siobhan encountered another person like herself, she was standing in the reading room of Belfast's Central Library on a Wednesday afternoon in late November, researching historical woodworking techniques for a restoration project that had been commissioned by the Ulster Folk Museum. The library's Victorian architecture created a cathedral-like atmosphere that usually helped her concentrate on detailed research, with its high ceilings, tall windows, and the hushed reverence that seemed to permeate spaces dedicated to the preservation and sharing of human knowledge. Her approach across the reading room felt charged with significance that went beyond casual social contact, carrying implications that Siobhan couldn't fully anticipate but that seemed likely to reshape her understanding of her condition and its place in the broader world. "Individuals with abilities similar to yours who were living ordinary lives until they were identified and approached by representatives of these organizations. The prospect of being forced into service with unknown agencies or organizations, or of being subjected to involuntary study and experimentation, represented dangers that she had never considered but that now seemed entirely plausible given the evidence that Dr. Blackwood was presenting. The comfortable assumption that her abilities were essentially private and harmless had been shattered, replaced by awareness that she existed in a world where such capabilities were valuable enough to justify extreme measures by people with substantial resources and questionable scruples.

"I need time to consider what you've told me and to verify at least some of your claims independently before making any commitments," Siobhan said, recognizing that the conversation had reached a point where further discussion would require decisions that she wasn't prepared to make without careful reflection and analysis. "If there really are people tracking me because of my condition, then I need to take immediate precautions to protect myself and my family, but I can't simply accept everything you've told me without some kind of independent confirmation. How can I contact you if I decide that I want to learn more about this network you've described, and what should I do in the meantime to avoid attracting additional attention from these surveillance organizations?"

The precautions she recommended were specific enough to be practical while being general enough to avoid revealing details about the network's methods or membership, striking a balance between helpful guidance and appropriate caution about sharing sensitive information with someone who hadn't yet committed to joining their community. Her manner throughout the conversation had been professional and respectful, acknowledging Siobhan's need for independence and verification while making clear that the dangers they faced required prompt decisions and decisive action rather than extended deliberation.

As Dr. Blackwood prepared to leave, she offered one final piece of advice that highlighted both the urgency of Siobhan's situation and the broader context that gave meaning to her individual struggles with invisibility and enhanced perception. "Your abilities are continuing to develop, which means that you're becoming more visible to the people who are looking for individuals like us," she said, rising from her chair and gathering her materials with movements that suggested both confidence and wariness about their public location. "Whatever you decide about joining our network, you need to understand that neutrality isn't really an option anymore. The surveillance organizations have resources and persistence that make it very difficult to simply opt out of their attention once you've been identified as someone with unusual capabilities. The choice isn't really between engagement and isolation, but between choosing your allies carefully and finding yourself forced to deal with people whose interests are fundamentally opposed to your freedom and safety."

After Dr. Blackwood left the library, Siobhan remained at her table for nearly an hour, staring at the historical woodworking texts that had brought her there while trying to process revelations that challenged every assumption she had developed about her condition and its implications for her future. The comfortable fiction that her invisible episodes were essentially private experiences that affected only her immediate relationships had been destroyed, replaced by awareness that she existed in a world where such abilities attracted attention from powerful organizations with their own agendas and questionable methods. The research project that had brought her to the library seemed trivial compared to the immediate need to assess her situation and develop strategies for protecting herself and her loved ones from threats that she was only beginning to understand.

The comfortable anonymity of city life had been replaced by the unsettling knowledge that her unusual capabilities made her inherently visible to people who viewed such abilities as resources to be acquired or eliminated rather than aspects of individual identity to be respected and protected.

Her relationship with Patricia, who was now deployed in South Sudan and completely vulnerable to any pressure that might be applied to influence Siobhan's cooperation with hostile organizations, created particular anxiety about the wisdom of any course of action that might escalate conflict with powerful adversaries. Similarly, Declan and Aoife's upcoming wedding and their plans for building a family together could be disrupted or destroyed if her condition created security risks that extended to her immediate relatives and their associates.

As she prepared for bed, Siobhan made detailed notes about her conversation with Dr. Blackwood, documenting both the specific information she had received and her emotional and intellectual responses to revelations that had fundamentally altered her understanding of her situation and her options for dealing with it. The writing process helped organize her thoughts while also creating a record that might prove valuable if she needed to reconstruct the conversation or analyze Dr. Blackwood's claims in greater detail. The journal that had begun as a simple record of her invisible episodes had evolved into a comprehensive documentation of her transformation from an ordinary person dealing with unusual experiences into someone whose very existence posed challenges and opportunities that attracted attention from powerful organizations with their own complex agendas.

The night passed restlessly, interrupted by dreams where she moved through landscapes that shifted between familiar Belfast locations and strange territories that seemed to exist outside normal geography, pursued by figures whose faces she could never quite see clearly but whose intentions felt unmistakably hostile. The rain hammered against the workshop windows with the persistence of an old debt collector, each droplet carrying the weight of another grey Belfast morning. Siobhan O'Malley wiped sawdust from her calloused hands and stepped back to admire the oak cabinet she'd been crafting for the past three weeks. The grain flowed like music across its surface, each whorl and line telling stories older than the troubles that had shaped her city.

At thirty-two, Siobhan had inherited more than just her father's workshop on Cromwell Street. She'd inherited his stubborn streak, his eye for detail, and his complete inability to suffer fools gladly. What she hadn't inherited was his easy way with people or his knack for making friends in high places. Those skills might have served her better in a trade still dominated by men who looked at her calloused hands and grease-stained apron with barely concealed skepticism.

The bell above her workshop door chimed, and Declan Murphy shouldered his way inside, shaking raindrops from his wool coat. Her step-brother moved through the world with the confidence of someone who'd never doubted his place in it, his dark hair perfectly styled despite the weather, his smile as practiced as a politician's handshake.

"Still playing with your toys, I see," he said, running a manicured finger along the cabinet's edge. "Though I'll admit, this one's not half bad."

Siobhan bristled. "Playing? This piece is going to the Merchant Hotel. They're paying three thousand pounds for my toys."

"Three thousand?" Declan's eyebrows rose. "Christ, maybe I should have learned to swing a hammer instead of studying law."

"You'd have needed to develop actual skills first." The words slipped out before she could stop them, sharp as the chisels hanging on her wall. Declan's smile faltered for just a moment before reassembling itself.

"Always the charmer, our Siobhan. Listen, I didn't come here to trade insults. Mam wants us both for Sunday dinner. Apparently, she's got some announcement to make."

Their mother, Patricia, had married Siobhan's father when Siobhan was barely fifteen. The woman had swept into their lives like a hurricane, reorganizing everything from the spice rack to their social calendar. When Siobhan's father died two years later, Patricia had stayed, bringing her own son Declan into the fold with his university education and his grand plans for the future.

"I'll be there," Siobhan said, though the prospect filled her with the same enthusiasm she reserved for root canals and tax audits.

Declan lingered by the door, his confidence seeming to waver. "There's something else. I've been meaning to tell you... I've met someone."

"Congratulations. Does she know about your personality yet?"

"Her name's Aoife Brennan. She's a teacher at St. Mary's Primary. And before you say anything cutting, I actually think this might be serious."

Something in his tone made Siobhan look up from her work. Declan's usual swagger had been replaced by something almost vulnerable, a crack in the armor he usually wore so effortlessly.

"Well then," she said, softer now. "I suppose I should meet this miracle worker who's managed to improve your disposition."

After Declan left, Siobhan returned to her work, but concentration proved elusive. The workshop felt smaller somehow, the familiar sounds of sanding and sawing unable to drown out the restlessness that had been growing in her chest for months. She'd always found solace in creating things with her hands, in transforming rough lumber into objects of beauty and function. But lately, even that satisfaction felt hollow.

The accident happened just after five o'clock, as the autumn light was fading into the purple dusk that settled over Belfast like a worn blanket. Siobhan was adjusting the blade on her table saw when the phone rang. Startled, she jerked backward, her elbow catching the edge of a paint can perched precariously on her workbench. The can tumbled, spilling wood stain across the concrete floor in a spreading pool of amber.

She lunged forward to catch the can, her foot slipping on the wet surface. Time seemed to slow as she felt herself falling, her head aimed directly for the corner of her workbench. In that suspended moment between balance and catastrophe, something strange happened. The world around her seemed to shift, colors bleeding together like watercolors in rain. She felt herself becoming lighter, less substantial, as if she were dissolving into the very air around her.

When she hit the ground, she felt no pain. In fact, she felt nothing at all. Confused, she pushed herself to her feet and looked around the workshop. Everything appeared normal except for one impossible detail: she couldn't see herself. Where her body should have been, there was nothing but empty space.

Panic rose in her throat like bile. She ran to the small mirror she kept by the washbasin, but her reflection was nowhere to be found. Only the workshop behind her stared back, complete and undisturbed. She waved her hands in front of the glass, but nothing moved except the shadows cast by the overhead lights.

"What the hell," she whispered, though she couldn't see her lips moving. The sound seemed to come from everywhere and nowhere at once.

She tried to convince herself it was a head injury, a hallucination brought on by the fall. But when she looked down at her hands, there was nothing there. She could feel them, could move her fingers and clench her fists, but they existed in a world beyond sight.

Over the next hour, she experimented with her condition like a scientist studying a new species. She could touch objects, could feel their texture and weight, but she cast no shadow and made no reflection. When she walked past the windows facing the street, pedestrians looked through her as if she were made of glass and air.

The invisibility lasted exactly three hours and seventeen minutes. She knew because she'd been watching the clock on her workbench when her body began to materialize again, starting with her fingertips and spreading up her arms like morning light chasing away shadows. The sensation was neither painful nor pleasant, simply strange, as if she were remembering how to exist in the physical world.

When she was fully visible again, she sat heavily on her work stool and tried to process what had happened. In a city where the impossible was usually reserved for ghost stories and political promises, she had somehow stepped outside the boundaries of the visible world and returned to tell the tale.

The workshop fell silent except for the steady drumming of rain against glass and the distant hum of Belfast traffic. Siobhan stared at her hands, turning them over in the lamplight, searching for some sign that they had been translucent mere minutes before. Her palms looked exactly as they always had—scarred from years of woodworking, a thin white line across her left thumb from a chisel that had slipped when she was seventeen, calluses thick as leather from gripping tools. Nothing had changed, yet everything felt different.

She stood on unsteady legs and walked to the window, pressing her palm against the cool glass. Her reflection stared back, solid and undeniable. A woman with auburn hair escaping from its ponytail, green eyes wide with confusion, wearing the same paint-splattered work clothes she'd put on that morning. But the memory of looking into the mirror and seeing nothing lingered like smoke in her mind, too vivid to dismiss as imagination.

The logical part of her brain, the part that measured twice and cut once, that understood angles and grain patterns and the precise amount of pressure needed to drive a screw without splitting wood, scrambled for explanations. Concussion from the fall, perhaps. She'd heard of head injuries causing hallucinations, though she couldn't remember hitting her head. Or maybe she'd inhaled too many paint fumes—the workshop ventilation had never been what it should be, despite her best efforts to improve it. But even as she grasped for rational causes, something deeper knew with absolute certainty that what had happened was real.

The phone rang again, the sound sharp enough to make her jump. She let it ring twice before answering, her voice catching slightly as she spoke. "O'Malley Woodworking."

"Siobhan, love, where have you been? I've been trying to reach you for ages." Her mother's voice carried the particular blend of affection and exasperation that Patricia had perfected over the years. "I wanted to make sure you remembered about Sunday dinner. We're having it at three instead of the usual time because Father McKenna is coming by afterward to discuss the church renovation project."

"I'll be there," Siobhan managed, though the normalcy of the conversation felt surreal after what she'd experienced. Her mother continued talking about menu plans and whether Declan would bring his new girlfriend, but the words seemed to come from very far away. How could the world continue spinning on its axis when she had just discovered that the fundamental rules of existence were apparently more flexible than she'd ever imagined?

After hanging up, she began the ritual of closing the workshop, a routine so ingrained she could do it in her sleep. Tools returned to their designated places on the pegboard, wood scraps sorted into bins for future projects, surfaces wiped clean of dust and debris. The familiar tasks helped ground her, each completed action a small anchor to reality. But as she swept up the spilled wood stain, now dried to a sticky amber patch on the concrete floor, she couldn't shake the feeling that she was playacting at normalcy.

The walk home through the narrow streets of Belfast should have been comforting. She'd taken this route thousands of times, past the corner shop where Mrs. Kelly always had a smile and a comment about the weather, past the pub where her father used to stop for a pint after work, past the small terraced houses with their brightly painted doors and postage-stamp gardens. Tonight, though, the familiar sights felt like a movie set, as if she were observing them from behind glass rather than moving through them as a participant.

Her flat occupied the upper floor of a Victorian house that had been converted into apartments sometime in the 1980s. The renovation had been done on the cheap, with thin walls that meant she knew more about her neighbors' lives than she cared to, and plumbing that groaned and complained at the slightest provocation. But it was hers, bought with money saved from years of careful budgeting and the small inheritance her father had left her. The independence it represented mattered more than its shortcomings.

She climbed the narrow staircase, her footsteps echoing in the hallway, and let herself into the flat. The living room was small but comfortable, furnished with pieces she'd made herself—a coffee table crafted from reclaimed barn wood, bookshelves that fit perfectly into the alcoves on either side of the fireplace, a rocking chair that had been her first major project after taking over the workshop. Creating furniture for her own space had always given her a particular satisfaction, each piece chosen and shaped to suit her needs exactly.

Tonight, though, even these familiar objects felt somehow foreign. She moved through the flat like a guest, touching surfaces tentatively, as if testing whether her fingers would pass through them like a ghost's. In the bathroom mirror, her reflection looked back with wide, uncertain eyes.
